cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who does the voice of alistair in dragon age
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
To answer the question about who voices Alistair in Dragon Age, I need to recall the information related to the character and the game series. Alistair is a prominent character in the Dragon Age series, particularly in "Dragon Age: Origins." The voice actor for Alistair is known for his work in video games and other media. I will consider the most recognized voice actor associated with this character.

Answer:
The voice of Alistair in Dragon Age: Origins is provided by actor Steve Valentine.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who does the voice of alistair in dragon age
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Alistair (Dragon Age)\n', 'Alistair was mainly written by David Gaider—the lead writer of "Origins"—and is voiced by Steve Valentine. Alistair is a relatively new Grey Warden, who are a group devoted to fighting darkspawn. He\'s believed to be the secret son of King Maric and a serving girl, and was originally raised in Redcliffe Castle by Arl Eamon after his mother\'s death. However, he was later given to the Chantry for training as a templar, a military order who are trained to kill "apostates" (mages outside of the Circle of Magi) and watch over the Circle of Magi. Alistair is described as having a "wry sense of humor", and makes many sarcastic remarks during the game.\n', 'BULLET::::- Alistair, a main character from the video game "Dragon Age: Origins"\n', 'Alistair was originally written to be a "grizzled Grey Warden veteran", as per "Dragon Age"s original lead designer James Ohlen. However, such a character would be unlikely not to lead, and the character would have to start out at a low level. Gaider changed the character, and drew some inspiration from the characters Xander Harris and Mal Reynolds. Similarly, Gaider also originally wanted to have Mal\'s actor Nathan Fillion voice the character, but decided against it as he would have had to perform an English accent. However, Gaider was still pleased with Valentine\'s voicing.\n', 'In the digital comics "Dragon Age: Those Who Speak" (which states that Alistair is king of Ferelden and that Hawke killed the Arishok in "Dragon Age II"), Sten is revealed to be the new Arishok and captures Alistair, Isabella, and Varric Tethras. When the three try to escape, the Arishok confronts Varric and Alistair. The fight turns into a duel between the Arishok and Alistair, who ultimately overpowers the Qunari. Instead of delivering the final blow, however, Alistair offers to form an alliance with the Arishok against their common enemy: Magister Aurelius Titus, who was apparently involved in King Maric\'s disappearance and seeks Alistair for his blood. The Arishok agrees, and Alistair, Varric, Isabella, and the Arishok sail to Titus\'s stronghold.\n', 'Alistair first appears in "Dragon Age: Origins" as a companion once the player reaches Ostagar (where the Grey Wardens are preparing for a battle against the darkspawn). Being a junior Grey Warden, he accompanies the player for their "Joining" to the Grey Wardens. After Loghain abandons the battle at Ostagar, leaving the Grey Wardens and King Cailan to die, he and the player are rescued by Flemeth. Being the last Grey Wardens in Ferelden, and all other Wardens being too far away to reach, the player and he must use Grey Warden contracts to demand help from certain groups against the darkspawn. Alistair also suggests contacting Arl Eamon, who resides in Redcliffe, to help convince the other nobles to help the player. Upon entering Redcliffe, Alistair will tell the player how he is actually the heir to the crown, but was hidden due to being a bastard and instead brought up by Eamon. He also expresses no wish to be king. He will then tell the player about his long-lost sister Goldanna, who lives in Denerim, and will ask to meet her. If brought to Goldanna, she will reject him, and the player may "harden" Alistair and tell him to stand up for himself more.\n', 'Alistair is a fictional character from BioWare\'s "Dragon Age" franchise, first appearing as a companion and party member in "". Alistair is the first full companion the player gets if they don\'t choose the Human Noble origin (and the second if they do), and is a fellow Grey Warden alongside the player character. Over the course of the game, Alistair is revealed to be the heir to Ferelden\'s throne, and may be put on as king. It is also possible to sacrifice him at the end of the game against the archdemon.\n', 'Main article: Alistair (Dragon Age)\n', 'Alistair returns in "" should he become King after the events of "". As long as he survived the events of "", he will make a cameo appearance in "Dragon Age II" and Dragon Age Inquisition as a temporary Grey Warden companion or as the King of Ferelden depending on the Dragon Age Keep tapestry.\n', 'Then for "Dragon Age 2", released in 2011, came Adam\'s breakthrough as Anders. Originally played by "Greg Ellis (actor)" in Dragon Age: Origins – Awakening, BioWare offered Adam the part when Greg couldn\'t perform it due to unspecified reasons that reduced his involvement in the second part only to apparitions as Cullen. With that new role, Adam returned in Dragon Age\'s universe, recording his voices with Catherine Livingstone who, back in Canada, guided Adam in his sessions; either by advising him on Anders\'s progression — as actors do not receive a complete script for secrecy reasons — and checking over his voice tone so that it didn\'t derail. In preparation for the role, Adam also listened to Greg Ellis\'s performance. But as the character had evolved from the first installment where he was cheerful, Adam followed his instincts since Anders, as the actor explains, "is written quite differently. He maintains a sense of humor but you learn so much more about him in DA2 and you see a much darker side to him."\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

The passages provide a comprehensive overview of the character Alistair from the "Dragon Age" franchise, particularly focusing on his role in "Dragon Age: Origins." Here are some key points and concepts that may be unfamiliar or provide additional context:

1. **Character Background**: Alistair is described as a relatively new Grey Warden, a group dedicated to fighting darkspawn. He is believed to be the secret son of King Maric and a serving girl, which adds complexity to his character and motivations. This lineage influences his interactions with other characters and his potential role as a leader.

2. **Voice Actor**: Alistair is voiced by Steve Valentine. This detail is significant because voice acting can greatly influence how a character is perceived by players. The choice of Valentine for this role was a decision made by David Gaider, the lead writer, who initially considered Nathan Fillion but opted for Valentine instead.

3. **Character Development**: The passages mention that Alistair was originally conceived as a "grizzled Grey Warden veteran," but this was changed to make him a younger character with a "wry sense of humor." This evolution in character design reflects the creative process in game development and how character traits can be adjusted to fit narrative needs.

4. **Narrative Role**: Alistair serves as a companion to the player character and plays a crucial role in the storyline, including revealing his royal lineage and his reluctance to assume the throne. His character arc includes themes of identity, duty, and personal growth, which are common in role-playing games.

5. **Game Mechanics**: The passages hint at game mechanics, such as the player's ability to influence Alistair's character development (e.g., "hardening" him) and the potential outcomes of his fate (e.g., sacrificing him against the archdemon). This interactivity is a hallmark of RPGs and emphasizes player agency.

6. **Cameo Appearances**: Alistair's appearances in subsequent games ("Dragon Age II" and "Dragon Age: Inquisition") as either a temporary companion or as the King of Ferelden highlight the continuity of character development across the franchise. This aspect of storytelling can enhance player investment in characters.

7. **Cultural References**: The character's design was influenced by popular culture, specifically mentioning characters like Xander Harris from "Buffy the Vampire Slayer" and Mal Reynolds from "Firefly." This intertextuality can enrich the character's appeal and relatability.

### Analysis of the Role of These Contents:

- **Character Depth**: The background information about Alistair's lineage and his role as a Grey Warden adds depth to his character, making him more relatable and complex. Players are often drawn to characters with rich backstories and personal conflicts.

- **Voice Acting Impact**: Knowing that Steve Valentine voices Alistair allows for an appreciation of the performance that brings the character to life. Voice acting can significantly affect player immersion and emotional connection to the character.

- **Narrative Flexibility**: The evolution of Alistair's character from a veteran to a younger, more humorous figure demonstrates the flexibility in character design that can lead to more engaging storytelling. This adaptability can resonate with players who appreciate character growth.

- **Player Agency**: The mechanics that allow players to influence Alistair's development and fate emphasize the interactive nature of RPGs. This agency is a key component of player engagement and investment in the story.

- **Cultural Resonance**: The references to other characters from popular media suggest that Alistair's design is part of a broader cultural dialogue, which can enhance player recognition and enjoyment.

Overall, these passages provide a rich context for understanding Alistair as a character within the "Dragon Age" series, highlighting the interplay between narrative, character development, and player interaction.

The voice of Alistair in "Dragon Age: Origins" is provided by actor Steve Valentine.

Over the course of the game, Alistair is revealed to be the heir to Ferelden's throne, and may be put on as king. It is also possible to sacrifice him at the end of the game against the archdemon.
', 'Main article: Alistair (Dragon Age)
', 'Alistair returns in "" should he become King after the events of "". As long as he survived the events of "", he will make a cameo appearance in "Dragon Age II" and Dragon Age Inquisition as a temporary Grey Warden companion or as the King of Ferelden depending on the Dragon Age Keep tapestry.
', 'Then for "Dragon Age 2", released in 2011, came Adam's breakthrough as Anders. Originally played by "Greg Ellis (actor)" in Dragon Age: Origins – Awakening, BioWare offered Adam the part when Greg couldn't perform it due to unspecified reasons that reduced his involvement in the second part only to apparitions as Cullen. With that new role, Adam returned in Dragon Age's universe, recording his voices with Catherine Livingstone who, back in Canada, guided Adam in his sessions; either by advising him on Anders's progression — as actors do not receive a complete script for secrecy reasons — and checking over his voice tone so that it didn't derail. In preparation for the role, Adam also listened to Greg Ellis's performance. But as the character had evolved from the first installment where he was cheerful, Adam followed his instincts since Anders, as the actor explains, "is written quite differently. He maintains a sense of humor but you learn so much more about him in DA2 and you see a much darker side to him."
']

['Alistair (Dragon Age)\n', 'Alistair was mainly written by David Gaider—the lead writer of "Origins"—and is voiced by Steve Valentine. Alistair is a relatively new Grey Warden, who are a group devoted to fighting darkspawn. He\'s believed to be the secret son of King Maric and a serving girl, and was originally raised in Redcliffe Castle by Arl Eamon after his mother\'s death. However, he was later given to the Chantry for training as a templar, a military order who are trained to kill "apostates" (mages outside of the Circle of Magi) and watch over the Circle of Magi. Alistair is described as having a "wry sense of humor", and makes many sarcastic remarks during the game.\n', 'BULLET::::- Alistair, a main character from the video game "Dragon Age: Origins"\n', 'Alistair was originally written to be a "grizzled Grey Warden veteran", as per "Dragon Age"s original lead designer James Ohlen. However, such a character would be unlikely not to lead, and the character would have to start out at a low level. Gaider changed the character, and drew some inspiration from the characters Xander Harris and Mal Reynolds. Similarly, Gaider also originally wanted to have Mal\'s actor Nathan Fillion voice the character, but decided against it as he would have had to perform an English accent. However, Gaider was still pleased with Valentine\'s voicing.\n', 'In the digital comics "Dragon Age: Those Who Speak" (which states that Alistair is king of Ferelden and that Hawke killed the Arishok in "Dragon Age II"), Sten is revealed to be the new Arishok and captures Alistair, Isabella, and Varric Tethras. When the three try to escape, the Arishok confronts Varric and Alistair. The fight turns into a duel between the Arishok and Alistair, who ultimately overpowers the Qunari. Instead of delivering the final blow, however, Alistair offers to form an alliance with the Arishok against their common enemy: Magister Aurelius Titus, who was apparently involved in King Maric\'s disappearance and seeks Alistair for his blood. The Arishok agrees, and Alistair, Varric, Isabella, and the Arishok sail to Titus\'s stronghold.\n', 'Alistair first appears in "Dragon Age: Origins" as a companion once the player reaches Ostagar (where the Grey Wardens are preparing for a battle against the darkspawn). Being a junior Grey Warden, he accompanies the player for their "Joining" to the Grey Wardens. After Loghain abandons the battle at Ostagar, leaving the Grey Wardens and King Cailan to die, he and the player are rescued by Flemeth. Being the last Grey Wardens in Ferelden, and all other Wardens being too far away to reach, the player and he must use Grey Warden contracts to demand help from certain groups against the darkspawn. Alistair also suggests contacting Arl Eamon, who resides in Redcliffe, to help convince the other nobles to help the player. Upon entering Redcliffe, Alistair will tell the player how he is actually the heir to the crown, but was hidden due to being a bastard and instead brought up by Eamon. He also expresses no wish to be king. He will then tell the player about his long-lost sister Goldanna, who lives in Denerim, and will ask to meet her. If brought to Goldanna, she will reject him, and the player may "harden" Alistair and tell him to stand up for himself more.\n', 'Alistair is a fictional character from BioWare\'s "Dragon Age" franchise, first appearing as a companion and party member in "". As long as he survived the events of "", he will make a cameo appearance in "Dragon Age II" and Dragon Age Inquisition as a temporary Grey Warden companion or as the King of Ferelden depending on the Dragon Age Keep tapestry.\n', 'Then for "Dragon Age 2", released in 2011, came Adam\'s breakthrough as Anders. Originally played by "Greg Ellis (actor)" in Dragon Age: Origins – Awakening, BioWare offered Adam the part when Greg couldn\'t perform it due to unspecified reasons that reduced his involvement in the second part only to apparitions as Cullen. With that new role, Adam returned in Dragon Age\'s universe, recording his voices with Catherine Livingstone who, back in Canada, guided Adam in his sessions; either by advising him on Anders\'s progression — as actors do not receive a complete script for secrecy reasons — and checking over his voice tone so that it didn\'t derail. In preparation for the role, Adam also listened to Greg Ellis\'s performance. But as the character had evolved from the first installment where he was cheerful, Adam followed his instincts since Anders, as the actor explains, "is written quite differently. He maintains a sense of humor but you learn so much more about him in DA2 and you see a much darker side to him."\n']

question_info.question: who does the voice of alistair in dragon age
passages:
Alistair (Dragon Age)
Alistair was mainly written by David Gaider—the lead writer of "Origins"—and is voiced by Steve Valentine. Alistair is a relatively new Grey Warden, who are a group devoted to fighting darkspawn. He's believed to be the secret son of King Maric and a serving girl, and was originally raised in Redcliffe Castle by Arl Eamon after his mother's death. However, he was later given to the Chantry for training as a templar, a military order who are trained to kill "apostates" (mages outside of the Circle of Magi) and watch over the Circle of Magi. Alistair is described as having a "wry sense of humor", and makes many sarcastic remarks during the game.
BULLET::::- Alistair, a main character from the video game "Dragon Age: Origins"
Alistair was originally written to be a "grizzled Grey Warden veteran", as per "Dragon Age"s original lead designer James Ohlen. However, such a character would be unlikely not to lead, and the character would have to start out at a low level. Gaider changed the character, and drew some inspiration from the characters Xander Harris and Mal Reynolds. Similarly, Gaider also originally wanted to have Mal's actor Nathan Fillion voice the character, but decided against it as he would have had to perform an English accent. However, Gaider was still pleased with Valentine's voicing.
In the digital comics "Dragon Age: Those Who Speak" (which states that Alistair is king of Ferelden and that Hawke killed the Arishok in "Dragon Age II"), Sten is revealed to be the new Arishok and captures Alistair, Isabella, and Varric Tethras. When the three try to escape, the Arishok confronts Varric and Alistair. The fight turns into a duel between the Arishok and Alistair, who ultimately overpowers the Qunari. Instead of delivering the final blow, however, Alistair offers to form an alliance with the Arishok against their common enemy: Magister Aurelius Titus, who was apparently involved in King Maric's disappearance and seeks Alistair for his blood. The Arishok agrees, and Alistair, Varric, Isabella, and the Arishok sail to Titus's stronghold.
Alistair first appears in "Dragon Age: Origins" as a companion once the player reaches Ostagar (where the Grey Wardens are preparing for a battle against the darkspawn). Being a junior Grey Warden, he accompanies the player for their "Joining" to the Grey Wardens. After Loghain abandons the battle at Ostagar, leaving the Grey Wardens and King Cailan to die, he and the player are rescued by Flemeth. Being the last Grey Wardens in Ferelden, and all other Wardens being too far away to reach, the player and he must use Grey Warden contracts to demand help from certain groups against the darkspawn. Alistair also suggests contacting Arl Eamon, who resides in Redcliffe, to help convince the other nobles to help the player. Upon entering Redcliffe, Alistair will tell the player how he is actually the heir to the crown, but was hidden due to being a bastard and instead brought up by Eamon. He also expresses no wish to be king. He will then tell the player about his long-lost sister Goldanna, who lives in Denerim, and will ask to meet her. If brought to Goldanna, she will reject him, and the player may "harden" Alistair and tell him to stand up for himself more.
Alistair is a fictional character from BioWare's "Dragon Age" franchise, first appearing as a companion and party member in "". Alistair is the first full companion the player gets if they don't choose the Human Noble origin (and the second if they do), and is a fellow Grey Warden alongside the player character. Over the course of the game, Alistair is revealed to be the heir to Ferelden's throne, and may be put on as king. It is also possible to sacrifice him at the end of the game against the archdemon.
Main article: Alistair (Dragon Age)
Alistair returns in "" should he become King after the events of "". As long as he survived the events of "", he will make a cameo appearance in "Dragon Age II" and Dragon Age Inquisition as a temporary Grey Warden companion or as the King of Ferelden depending on the Dragon Age Keep tapestry.
Then for "Dragon Age 2", released in 2011, came Adam's breakthrough as Anders. Originally played by "Greg Ellis (actor)" in Dragon Age: Origins – Awakening, BioWare offered Adam the part when Greg couldn't perform it due to unspecified reasons that reduced his involvement in the second part only to apparitions as Cullen. With that new role, Adam returned in Dragon Age's universe, recording his voices with Catherine Livingstone who, back in Canada, guided Adam in his sessions; either by advising him on Anders's progression — as actors do not receive a complete script for secrecy reasons — and checking over his voice tone so that it didn't derail. In preparation for the role, Adam also listened to Greg Ellis's performance. But as the character had evolved from the first installment where he was cheerful, Adam followed his instincts since Anders, as the actor explains, "is written quite differently. He maintains a sense of humor but you learn so much more about him in DA2 and you see a much darker side to him."
